policy: FAFSA Independent Student Status - Foster Care
description: Students in foster care after age 13 are automatically independent for FAFSA
fafsa_question: Question 52: At any time since you turned age 13, were both your parents deceased, were you in foster care, or were you a dependent or ward of the court?
answer_yes_if: In foster care at any time after age 13
Ward of the court after age 13
efc_calculation: Based on student's income and assets only (not parents)
documentation_required: Court documents showing foster care placement
notes: Even if student is no longer in foster care, they remain independent for FAFSA if they were in foster care after age 13.

description: Federal grant for current and former foster youth
administering_agency: State foster care agencies (funded by federal government)
eligibility: In foster care at age 14 or older, OR adopted from foster care after age 16, OR in guardianship from foster care after age 16
age_limit: Up to age 26 (extended from age 23 in 2021)
award_amount_notes: $5,000 per year maximum (varies by state funding)
application_process: Apply through state foster care agency (varies by state)
stacking_notes: Can combine with Pell Grant, state aid, institutional aid

eligibility: Current or former foster youth, ward of the court, orphan, or emancipated minor
application_process: Apply to UC + indicate foster youth status on application + complete Guardian Scholars application
housing_benefit: Year-round housing (dorms stay open in summer, unlike regular students)
notes: UC Guardian Scholars is one of the best programs for foster youth. Provides comprehensive support beyond just financial aid.

eligibility: Current or former foster youth, ward of the court, orphan, or homeless youth
application_process: Apply to USC + indicate foster youth status + complete Trojan Guardian Scholars application
notes: USC Trojan Guardian Scholars provides full-ride + comprehensive support. One of the most generous programs for foster youth.

program: Stanford Opportunity Scholars - Foster Youth Track
eligibility: Current or former foster youth, ward of the court, or orphan
application_process: Apply to Stanford + indicate foster youth status on application
notes: Stanford provides full financial aid to foster youth (family contribution $0 for income <$150k).

application_process: Apply to CSU + contact Guardian Scholars program at specific campus
notes: CSU Guardian Scholars programs vary by campus. Not all CSU campuses have Guardian Scholars programs.

description: Foster care benefits extended to age 21 for youth who meet eligibility criteria
eligibility: In foster care on 18th birthday AND (enrolled in high school, enrolled in college, employed 80+ hours/month, OR unable to work due to medical condition)
application_process: Work with social worker before age 18 to plan for extended foster care
statute: California AB 12 (Fostering Connections to Success Act)
notes: AB 12 allows foster youth to receive support until age 21 while attending college. Can use foster care stipend to help pay for housing.

description: Free health insurance for former foster youth until age 26
eligibility: In foster care on 18th birthday in ANY state (not just CA)
benefits: Full Medi-Cal coverage (medical, dental, vision, mental health)
application_process: Apply through county social services or Covered California
documentation_required: Proof of foster care status (court documents, social worker letter)
notes: Former foster youth from ANY state can get Medi-Cal in CA if they move to CA. This is a huge benefit for college students.

policy: SSI (Supplemental Security Income) for Foster Youth
description: Federal disability benefits for low-income individuals with disabilities
eligibility: Disabled (physical or mental disability) AND low income AND low assets
monthly_benefit_notes: $914/month for individual (2025 federal rate; CA adds $200 state supplement = $1,114/month total)
asset_limit_notes: $2,000 asset limit (excludes car, home, personal belongings)
income_limit: Varies (SSI reduces $1 for every $2 earned above $85/month)
impact_on_fafsa: SSI is untaxed income - must report on FAFSA, increases EFC
able_account: Can save up to $18,000/year in ABLE account without affecting SSI asset limit
notes: Many foster youth receive SSI due to disabilities (PTSD, ADHD, etc.). SSI + foster care stipend + Chafee grant can provide significant support.

description: Tax-advantaged savings account for individuals with disabilities
asset_limit_exemption: ABLE account assets do NOT count toward SSI $2,000 asset limit (up to $100,000)
tax_benefits: Contributions are after-tax, but earnings grow tax-free and withdrawals are tax-free if used for qualified disability expenses
impact_on_financial_aid: ABLE account assets are NOT counted on FAFSA (as of 2024)
notes: ABLE accounts are great for foster youth receiving SSI who want to save for college without losing SSI benefits.

description: Dorms close in summer, leaving foster youth without housing
problem: Most college dorms close in summer. Foster youth may have nowhere to go (no family home to return to).
solutions: Summer employment with housing (RA positions, summer camps)
financial_aid_for_summer: Chafee grant can be used for summer. Some schools offer summer financial aid.
notes: Summer housing is a critical issue for foster youth. Guardian Scholars programs that provide year-round housing are essential.

description: Mental health challenges and support services for foster youth
common_challenges: Academic challenges due to school instability
disability_accommodations: Foster youth with PTSD, ADHD, etc. can register with disability services for accommodations (extended time, reduced course load, excused absences)
medi_cal_coverage: Former foster youth have Medi-Cal until age 26 (covers mental health treatment)
notes: Foster youth have high rates of mental health challenges due to trauma. Comprehensive support services are critical for success.

description: Legal status where minor is declared independent from parents
court_process: Must petition court for emancipation (requires proof of financial independence, housing, etc.)
impact_on_fafsa: Emancipated minors are NOT automatically independent for FAFSA (must meet other criteria like foster care after age 13)
financial_aid_implications: If emancipated but not in foster care, may need to provide parent info on FAFSA (unless meet other independent student criteria)
notes: Emancipation alone does NOT make student independent for FAFSA. Must also meet foster care or other criteria.

description: Homeless youth can be independent for FAFSA
fafsa_question: Question 53: At any time on or after July 1, 2024, did your high school or school district homeless liaison determine that you were an unaccompanied youth who was homeless or were self-supporting and at risk of being homeless?
answer_yes_if: Homeless liaison, HUD shelter director, or TRIO director confirms homeless status
documentation_required: Letter from homeless liaison, shelter director, or TRIO director
notes: Homeless youth (including foster youth who aged out and became homeless) can be independent for FAFSA.
